  • When the valuations are submodular, (Li et al. 2022) proved that no algorithm guarantees a better than nnn-MMS allocation. (Aziz et al. 2019) considered the case when the agents have asymmetric entitlements and extended the notion of weighted MMS to chores, but the tight approximation ratio is still unknown.

  • Relaxations of EF and PROP need to be changed a bit to capture the fact that the agents have negative values for chores. Essentially, instead of removing goods from bundles of other agents to eliminate the envy of an agent, we nned to remove chores from the bundle of the agent her self.

Definition for EF1 and EFX for chores: For chores, an allocation AAA is α\alphaα-EF1 if vi(Ai╲{g})≥α⋅vi(Aj)v_i(A_i\diagdown\{g\})\ge\alpha\cdot v_i(A_j)vi​(Ai​╲{g})≥α⋅vi​(Aj​) for any pair of agents i,ji,ji,j and some g∈Ag\in Ag∈A; AAA is α\alphaα-EFX if the inequality holds for any g∈Ag\in Ag∈A.

  • For additive valuations, an EF1 allocation can be easily computed by Round-Robin algorithm.

  • (Bhaskar et al. 2021) noted that the allocation returned by Ency-Cycle Elimination algorithm may not be EF1 if the cycles are resolved arbitrarily. Instead, the top-trading technique must be used to preserve EF1.

    In contrast to the case of goods where EF1 and PO can be satisfied simultaneously, the compatibility of EF1 and PO is still unknown for chores.

  • (Ebadian et al. 2022; Garg et al. 2022; Chaudhury et al. 2022) proved that for bi-valued instances, EF1+PO allocations always exist and can be found efficiently; this is the only known result so far.

  • The existence of EFX allocations for chores also remains open, with the only positive result being the computation of O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)-EFX allocations due to (Zhou and Wu 2022).

Other Settings

Some allocations may not be feasible due to various restrictions, such as connectivity, cardinality, separation or budet constriants.

  • (Suksompong 2021) discuss this part in detail.
  • (\Sheddighin et al. 2021) and (Aziz et al. 2021) studied externalities in fair division, where agents not only have value for what they get but also for what others get.
  • (Conitzer et al. 2017; Fain et al. 2018; Garg et al. 2021) related to public resource allocaation whre the items can be shared by the agents.
entry.summary: Iannis 给了三篇论文，三个方向。分别通读一下这三篇论文，看看什么主题比较感兴趣吧。

entry.title: 计算几何 W48 Robot Motion Planning and Visibility (新课完结)
entry.content:
Robot Motion Planning

Given a set of obstacles P1,⋯ ,PkP_1,\cdots,P_kP1​,⋯,Pk​, and a polygonal robot RRR with starting configuration sss and target configuration ttt. Find a path for the robot from sss to ttt if possible.

机器人路径规划问题，首先应该先解决：存不存在这样一条路径的问题。

Reference point

define a reference point ppp of the robot and define position of the vertices of RRR w.r.t. ppp.

Suppose our robot can move by translating

R(x,y)R(x,y)R(x,y): position of the robot when the reference point is at (x,y)(x,y)(x,y).

Suppose our robot can move by translating:

R(x,y,α)R(x,y,\alpha)R(x,y,α): position of the robot when the reference point is at (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and the robot has orientation α\alphaα.

We represent the robot by a point in the parameter space (configuration space) R2×[0,360)\mathbb R^2\times[0,360)R2×[0,360)

先只考虑机器人只能平移，不能旋转。

partition the configuration space in free space and forbidden space

ppp in forbidden space ⇔R(p)\Lrarr R(p)⇔R(p) intersects an obstacle.

RRR can move from sss to t⇔t\Lrarrt⇔ there is a path from sss to ttt in the free space.

对于机器人上的一个参考点，在图上都有一个 free space 图。如果 free space 联通起始点，那么就存在一个路径使得机器人可以从起点移动到终点。

if RRR is a point then configuration space = work space.

Finding a path in the Configuration Space

如果存在路径，那么就找出这样一条路径

given a configuration space P1,⋯ ,PkP_1,\cdots,P_kP1​,⋯,Pk​ of complexity nnn find a path from sss to ttt if possible.

idea: construct a trapezoidal decomposition of the free space.

思路：将 free space 用竖线进行梯形分解。

construct a road map G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)

VVV: set of all centers of all trapezoids Δ\DeltaΔ and all midpoints of all vertical segments sss.

梯形的中位线中点+所有梯形顶边和底边线段的中点

(Δ,s)∈E⇔s(\Delta,s)\in E\Lrarr s(Δ,s)∈E⇔s is a vertical segment bounding Δ\DeltaΔ.

add sss and ttt to GGG and connect them to the trapezoids containing them.

Run a BFS in the road map to find a path from sss to ttt.

Theorem

we can compute a path from sss to ttt in O(nlog⁡n)\mathcal O(n\log n)O(nlogn) expected time.

如何搞定 free space 的计算问题呢？使用闵可夫斯基和解决！

Minkowski Sums

Let PPP and RRR be two sets in R2\mathbb R^2R2

P\oplus R=\{p+r|p\in R\and r\in R\} is the Minkowski sum of PPP and RRR.

where p+r={px+rx,py+ry}p+r=\{p_x+r_x,p_y+r_y\}p+r={px​+rx​,py​+ry​}

observation: let Q=P⊕RQ=P\oplus RQ=P⊕R, an extreme point on QQQ in direction ddd is the sum of extreme points in direction ddd on PPP and RRR.

Theorem

  1. Let PPP and RRR be convex polygons with nnn and mmm edges, then Q=P⊕RQ=P\oplus RQ=P⊕R is a convex polygon and has at most m+nm+nm+n edges.
  2. Let PPP and RRR be convex polygons with nnn and mmm edges, then Q=P⊕RQ=P\oplus RQ=P⊕R can e computed in O(m+n)\mathcal O(m+n)O(m+n) time.

Question: What if PPP and RRR are not convex?

Pseudo-discs

a pair PPP and RRR are pseudo-discs

the boundaries of PPP and RRR intersect in at most two points.

i.e.,

∂P∩int(R) is connected and∂R∩int(P) is connected.\partial P\cap int(R)\text{ is connected and}\\\partial R\cap int(P)\text{ is connected.}∂P∩int(R) is connected and∂R∩int(P) is connected.

observation: A pair of polygonal pseudo-discs PPP and RRR defines at most two boundary crossing

Theorem

Let S\mathcal SS be a collection of convex polygonal pseudo-discs with a total of nnn edges. the total complexity of their union is at most 2n2n2n.

  • pseudo-disk vertices
  • intersection points

Charge every pseudo-disk vertex to itself.

For an intersection point q=e∩fq=e\cap fq=e∩f, by observation: either

  • eee has no other boundary crossing with \part R.
  • fff has no other boundary crossing with \part P, or both

Let eee be the edge without other boundary crossings, and let vvv be the endpoint of eee in RRR.

Charge qqq to vvv.

Claim: Every vertex vvv (of a pseudo-disk PPP) is charged at most twice.

  • Case 1: vvv not in any other pseudo-disk ∴ vvv is a green vertex and is charged only by itself.

  • Case 2: v,v∈Rv,v\in Rv,v∈R lies in the interior of the union.

    Traverse e=vw‾e=\overline{vw}e=vw. There is only one point qqq on the boundary of the union on eee that charges to vvv.

    Same for the other edge vu‾\overline{vu}vu

  • Case 3: v,v\in\part R lies on the boundary of the union. As in case 2 vvv is charged only by its incident edges eee and fff and by vvv itself

    vvv can not be charged by both its incident edges at the same time.

Let S\mathcal SS be a collection of pseudo-discs with a total of nnn edges. The total complexity of their union is at most O(n)O(n)O(n).

Observation: Let PPP and RRR be convex polygons with disjoint interiors, let d1d_1d1​ and d2d_2d2​ be directions where PPP is more extreme than RRR.

Then either

  • PPP is more extreme in all directions in [d1,d2][d_1,d_2][d1​,d2​], or
  • PPP is more extreme in all directions in [d2,d1][d_2,d_1][d2​,d1​].

Let PPP and QQQ be two convex polygons with disjoint interiors, and let RRR be another convex polygon. Then P⊕RP\oplus RP⊕R and Q⊕RQ\oplus RQ⊕R are pseudo-discs.

To show: \part P\oplus R\cap int(Q\oplus R) is connected.

Proof by contradiction. Assume \part P\oplus R\cap int(Q\oplus R) is not connected.

By observation, an extreme point on P⊕RP\oplus RP⊕R corresponds to a extreme point on PPP. Same for QQQ.

⇒P\Rarr P⇒P more extreme on dpd_pdp​ and dqd_qdq​ than QQQ

⇒Q\Rarr Q⇒Q more extreme on dsd_sds​ and drd_rdr​ than PPP

What if PPP is not convex?

observation: for any set P,Q,RP,Q,RP,Q,R

R⊕(P∪Q)=(R⊕P)∪(R⊕Q)R\oplus(P\cup Q)=(R\oplus P)\cup(R\oplus Q)R⊕(P∪Q)=(R⊕P)∪(R⊕Q)

Triangulate PPP

⇒\Rarr⇒ this produces a collection of disjoint convex polygons, so the collection of Minkowski sums is a collection of pseudo-disks.

Let PPP be a polygon with nnn vertices, and let RRR be a convex polygon with mmm vertices. Then complexity of P⊕RP\oplus RP⊕R is Θ(mn)\Theta(mn)Θ(mn).

What if PPP and RRR are both not convex?

Triangulate both PPP and RRR. This gives a collection of O(mn)O(mn)O(mn) triangles.

Let PPP be a polygon with nnn vertices, and let RRR be a convex polygon with mmm vertices, The complexity of P⊕RP\oplus RP⊕R is Θ(n2m2)\Theta(n^2m^2)Θ(n2m2).

Let PPP be a polygon with nnn vertices, and let RRR be a convex polygon with m=O(1)m=O(1)m=O(1) vertices, we can compute P⊕RP\oplus RP⊕R in O(n2log⁡n)\mathcal O(n^2\log n)O(n2logn) time.

好麻啊这一段

Minkowski Sum & Robot Motion Planning

Let −p=(−px,−py)-p=(-p_x,-p_y)−p=(−px​,−py​) and −S={−p∣p∈S}-\mathcal S=\{-p|p\in\mathcal S\}−S={−p∣p∈S}

Lemma. Let PPP be an obstacle and let RRR be a planar, translating robot. A point qqq in the configuration space is forbidden iff q∈P⊕(−R(0,0))q\in P\oplus(-R(0,0))q∈P⊕(−R(0,0)).

In direction:

suppose q∈P∩R(x,y)q\in P\cap R(x,y)q∈P∩R(x,y)

q∈R(x,y)⇒q−(x,y)∈R(0,0)−q+(x,y)∈−R(0,0)q∈P⇒(x,y)∈P⊕−(R(0,0))q\in R(x,y)\Rarr q-(x,y)\in R(0,0)\\-q+(x,y)\in-R(0,0)\\q\in P\Rarr(x,y)\in P\oplus-(R(0,0))q∈R(x,y)⇒q−(x,y)∈R(0,0)−q+(x,y)∈−R(0,0)q∈P⇒(x,y)∈P⊕−(R(0,0))

Only if direction: similar.

Question: How do we compute the free/forbidden space in the configuration space?

Forbidden space =∪iPi⊕−(R(0,0))=\cup_iP_i\oplus-(R(0,0))=∪i​Pi​⊕−(R(0,0))

So if RRR is convex and has constant complexity, and the input polygons have a total nnn vertices we can compute the forbidden space in O(nlog⁡2n)O(n\log^2n)O(nlog2n) time.

Shortest Paths

Given a set of obstacles P1,⋯ ,PhP_1,\cdots,P_hP1​,⋯,Ph​, a starting point sss and target point ttt. Find a shortest path from sss to ttt,

Lemma A shortest pat between sss and ttt among a st of disjoint obstacles P1,⋯ ,PhP_1,\cdots,P_hP1​,⋯,Ph​ is a polygonal path whose inner vertices are vertices of P1,⋯ ,PhP_1,\cdots,P_hP1​,⋯,Ph​.

Question: how do we compute a shortest path between sss and ttt?

idea: Construct a graph G=(V,E,w)G=(V,E,w)G=(V,E,w) with edge length s.t. for (u,v)∈E(u,v)\in E(u,v)∈E the edge corresponds to the distance between uuu and vvv.

V=V=V= the set of obstacle vertex vvv and sss and ttt

(u,v)∈E⇔u(u,v)\in E\Lrarr u(u,v)∈E⇔u and vvv can see each other

w(u,v)=∣∣uv∣∣w(u,v)=||uv||w(u,v)=∣∣uv∣∣

Theorem: We can compute GGG in O(n2log⁡n)O(n^2\log n)O(n2logn) time.

Visibility Graph

Connecting two vertices if they can see each other.

Sub-goal: compute all visible vertices from any point ppp in O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn) time.

i.e. visibility graph in O(n2log⁡n)O(n^2\log n)O(n2logn) time.

Idea: Radical sweep ray!

Exactly identical to normal sweep line, if we rotate the ball until ppp is a point at infinity.

我的理解是把这个看成以该点为极点的极坐标，可以映射到一个以该点为原点的直角坐标。就可以转化为最普通的扫描线了。

Find vertices visible from ∞\infty∞ X-coordinate.

Compute visible vertices from sss to ttt, add to visibility graph, then use Dijkstra for O(n2log⁡n)O(n^2\log n)O(n2logn) time in total.

(can be improved to O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn))

entry.title: 算法博弈论 W48 Potential games and price of stability (新课完结)
entry.content:
Cut games

Graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) with weight wew_ewe​ on each edge e∈Ee\in Ee∈E.

Every node corresponds to a player.

Two strategies per player/node vvv:

  • To put vvv at the left or right side of the cut

Cut(S)Cut(S)Cut(S): the set of edges with their endpoints on different sides of the cut at a state SSS

payoffi(S)=∑e∈Cut(S)∩Niwe\text{payoff}_i(S)=\sum_{e\in Cut(S)\cap N_i}w_epayoffi​(S)=e∈Cut(S)∩Ni​∑​we​

A pure Nash equilibrium was found.

带权图的最大割 Maximum cut

Cut games are potential games

Lemma: the function

Φ(S)=∑e∈Cut(S)we\Phi(S)=\sum_{e\in Cut(S)}w_eΦ(S)=e∈Cut(S)∑​we​

is a potential function for a cut game.

Proof

Consider two states SSS and S′S'S′ that differ in the strategy of player iii i.e., S′=(S−i,si′)S'=(S_{-i},s_i')S′=(S−i​,si′​)

we will show that Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=payoffi(S)−payoffi(S′)\Phi(S)-\Phi(S')=\text{payoff}_i(S)-\text{payoff}_i(S')Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=payoffi​(S)−payoffi​(S′)

Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=∑e∈Cut(S)we−∑e∈Cut(S′)we=∑e∈Cut(S)∩Niwe+∑e∈Cut(S)╲Niwe−∑e∈Cut(S′)∩Niwe−∑e∈Cut(S′)╲Niwe\Phi(S)-\Phi(S')=\sum_{e\in Cut(S)}w_e-\sum_{e\in Cut(S')}w_e\\=\sum_{e\in Cut(S)\cap N_i}w_e+\sum_{e\in Cut(S)\diagdown N_i}w_e-\sum_{e\in Cut(S')\cap N_i}w_e-\sum_{e\in Cut(S')\diagdown N_i}w_e\\Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=e∈Cut(S)∑​we​−e∈Cut(S′)∑​we​=e∈Cut(S)∩Ni​∑​we​+e∈Cut(S)╲Ni​∑​we​−e∈Cut(S′)∩Ni​∑​we​−e∈Cut(S′)╲Ni​∑​we​

Observe that the edges which belong to the cut but are not incident to node iii are the same in states SSS and S′S'S′, since they are not affected by the change of strategy for player iii. （与 iii 不相邻的点在其改变策略前后对势函数的贡献不变） Hence, we have:

=∑e∈Cut(S)∩Niwe+∑e∈Cut(S)╲Niwe−∑e∈Cut(S′)∩Niwe−∑e∈Cut(S′)╲Niwe=payoffi(S)−payoffi(S′)=\sum_{e\in Cut(S)\cap N_i}w_e+\cancel{\sum_{e\in Cut(S)\diagdown N_i}w_e}-\sum_{e\in Cut(S')\cap N_i}w_e-\cancel{\sum_{e\in Cut(S')\diagdown N_i}w_e}\\\\=\text{payoff}_i(S)-\text{payoff}_i(S')=e∈Cut(S)∩Ni​∑​we​+e∈Cut(S)╲Ni​∑​we​​−e∈Cut(S′)∩Ni​∑​we​−e∈Cut(S′)╲Ni​∑​we​​=payoffi​(S)−payoffi​(S′)

Price of anarchy/stability

Review: price of stability (defined in social cost) 如果用社会福利定义，分子分母反过来。

PoS=value of best Nash equilibriumvalue of optimal solution,PoS≥0PoS=\frac{\text{value of best Nash equilibrium}}{\text{value of optimal solution}},PoS\ge0PoS=value of optimal solutionvalue of best Nash equilibrium​,PoS≥0

The potential function mainly gives us information about the structure of the game. To assess the quality of states, we use the notion of the social welfare, defined as the total payoff of all players in state SSS, i.e. Social welfare: total payoff of all players in state SSS,

SW(S)=∑ipayoffi(S)SW(S)=\sum_i\text{payoff}_i(S)SW(S)=i∑​payoffi​(S)

Observation: SW(S)=2Φ(S)SW(S)=2\Phi(S)SW(S)=2Φ(S).

Proof:

（简单来讲，就是因为一条割边被记了两次 because two player share a cut edge while Φ(S)\Phi(S)Φ(S) only count cut edge once.）

By definition of the social welfare, we have

SW(S)=∑ipayoffi(S)=∑i∑e∈CUT(S)∩NiweSW(S)=\sum_i\text{payoff}_i(S)=\sum_i\sum_{e\in CUT(S)\cap N_i}w_eSW(S)=i∑​payoffi​(S)=i∑​e∈CUT(S)∩Ni​∑​we​

Now, observe that every edge in the cut contributes to the payoff the two players controlling its end points. Thus, we have:

SW(S)=∑e∈CUT(S)2we=2Φ(S)SW(S)=\sum_{e\in CUT(S)}2w_e=2\Phi(S)SW(S)=e∈CUT(S)∑​2we​=2Φ(S)

Hence the price of stability is equal to 1. (Why?)

Proof:

By Lemma proved above, notice that the state of maximum social welfare maximizes the value of the potential function and is, thus, an equilibrium. The theorem follows by the definition of the price of stability.

Theorem: The price of anarchy is at most 2

Proof

Similar to the proof that a simple local search algorithm for solving the MAX-CUT problem has good performance. MAX-CUT is formally defined as follows: Given a graph GGG with non-negative weights on the edges, find a partition of the nodes in two set so that the total weight of edges with their endpoints is different sets of the partition is maximized.

Let SeqS_{eq}Seq​ be a pure Nash equilibrium and uuu a node that is at the left of the cut in state SeqS_{eq}Seq​. Since SeqS_{eq}Seq​ is an equilibrium, the player controlling node uuu has no incentive to deviate from her strategy.

This means that the total weight of edges in the cut which are incident to uuu is at least half the total weight of all edges which are incident to uuu. Thus, for every player at the left of the cut, we have:

payoffu(Seq)=∑e∈CUT(Seq)∩Nuwe≥12∑e∈Nuwe\text{payoff}_u(S_{eq})=\sum_{e\in CUT(S_{eq})\cap N_u}w_e\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{e\in N_u}w_epayoffu​(Seq​)=e∈CUT(Seq​)∩Nu​∑​we​≥21​e∈Nu​∑​we​

Using similar reasoning, we can verify an analogous for the nodes at right of the cut. Summing over all players and using the definition of social welfare, we have

SW(Seq)=∑u∈Vpayoffu(Seq)≥12∑u∈V∑e∈Nuwe=∑e∈EweSW(S_{eq})=\sum_{u\in V}\text{payoff}_u(S_{eq})\ge\frac{1}{2}\sum_{u\in V}\sum_{e\in N_u}w_e=\sum_{e\in E}w_eSW(Seq​)=u∈V∑​payoffu​(Seq​)≥21​u∈V∑​e∈Nu​∑​we​=e∈E∑​we​

The last equality follows since when we sum over all nodes, we count each edge e=(u,v)e=(u,v)e=(u,v) twice since eee belongs to both sets NuN_uNu​ and NvN_vNv​. Now, it suffices to observe that 2×∑e∈Ewe2\times\sum_{e\in E}w_e2×∑e∈E​we​ is a upper bound on the social welfare of any state, including the state S∗S^*S∗ of maximum social welfare. Indeed（一个点的 payoff 最多只能被所有与之相连的边贡献，SW(S∗)SW(S^*)SW(S∗) 不能超过所有点连出去的所有边权之和）:

SW(S∗)=∑u∈Vpayoffu(S∗)≤∑u∈V∑e∈Nuwe=2×∑e∈EweSW(S^*)=\sum_{u\in V}\text{payoff}_u(S^*)\le\sum_{u\in V}\sum_{e\in N_u}w_e=2\times\sum_{e\in E}w_eSW(S∗)=u∈V∑​payoffu​(S∗)≤u∈V∑​e∈Nu​∑​we​=2×e∈E∑​we​

Thus, we have SW(Seq)≥12SW(S∗)SW(S_{eq})\ge\frac{1}{2}SW(S^*)SW(Seq​)≥21​SW(S∗) Q. E. D.

Theorem: There exists cut games with PoA exactly 2

example:

a-1-b-1-c-1-d-1-a

ab cd: SW=4

ac bd: SW=8

Network design games

Graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E)

Cost wew_ewe​ for edge e∈Ee\in Ee∈E

  • indicates the cost of establishing the corresponding link in the network

nnn player

  • player iii want to connect a source σi\sigma_iσi​ to a destination node τi\tau_iτi​.
  • strategies: the different paths that connect node σi\sigma_iσi​ with node τi\tau_iτi​.

Cost of player iii at a state SSS where the strategy sis_isi​ is used for player iii

costi(S)=∑e∈siwefe(S)\text{cost}_i(S)=\sum_{e\in s_i}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}costi​(S)=e∈si​∑​fe​(S)we​​

fe(S)f_e(S)fe​(S): 在 SSS 状态下，使用 eee 边的玩家总数

Social cost = total cost of all players at a state

SC(S)=∑icosti(S)=∑i∑e∈siwefe(S)=∑e∈E∑i∈Ni,e∈siwefe(S)=∑e∈Ewefe(S)∑i∈Ni,e∈si1=∑e∈Ewe=sum of weights of edges used by at least one player.SC(S)=\sum_i\text{cost}_i(S)\\=\sum_i\sum_{e\in s_i}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}\\=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{i\in N_i,e\in s_i}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}\\=\sum_{e\in E}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}\sum_{i\in N_i,e\in s_i}1\\=\sum_{e\in E}w_e\\=\text{sum of weights of edges used by at least one player.}SC(S)=i∑​costi​(S)=i∑​e∈si​∑​fe​(S)we​​=e∈E∑​i∈Ni​,e∈si​∑​fe​(S)we​​=e∈E∑​fe​(S)we​​i∈Ni​,e∈si​∑​1=e∈E∑​we​=sum of weights of edges used by at least one player.

Alternatively, the total cost of the edges used by at least one player.

Theorem: There exists a network with PoA arbitrarily close to nnn

graph LRs((s))t((t))s-->|1+ε|ts-->|n|t

PoA=max⁡S∈PNESC(S)SC(S∗)PoS=min⁡S∈PNESC(S)SC(S∗)S∗:state of minimum social cost1≤PoS≤PoAPoA=\max_{S\in PNE}\frac{SC(S)}{SC(S^*)}\\PoS=\min_{S\in PNE}\frac{SC(S)}{SC(S^*)}\\S^*:\text{state of minimum social cost}\\1\le PoS\le PoAPoA=S∈PNEmax​SC(S∗)SC(S)​PoS=S∈PNEmin​SC(S∗)SC(S)​S∗:state of minimum social cost1≤PoS≤PoA

考虑一种均衡，当有 nnn 个玩家，全部都使用下面的路径，每个玩家的损失都是 111, 此时没有玩家有 incentive to 使用上面那条 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ 的路径。所以

PoA=1×n1+ϵn×n=n1+ϵ→nPoA=\frac{1\times n}{\frac{1+\epsilon}{n}\times n}=\frac{n}{1+\epsilon}\rightarrow nPoA=n1+ϵ​×n1×n​=1+ϵn​→n

Price of stability

Theorem: there exists a network design game with PoS arbitrarily close to Hn=∑i=1n1iH_n=\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{1}{i}Hn​=∑i=1n​i1​.

Proof:

>graph TB0((τ))1((0))s1((σ1))s2((σ2))s3((σ3))s((...))sn((σn))s1-->|1|0s2-->|1/2|0s3-->|1/3|0s-->|1/...|0sn-->|1/n|0s1-->|0|1s2-->|0|1s3-->|0|1s-->|0|1sn-->|0|11-->|1+ε|0

SC(S∗)=1+ϵSC(S)=∑i=1n1i=HnSC(S^*)=1+\epsilon\\SC(S)=\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{1}{i}=H_nSC(S∗)=1+ϵSC(S)=i=1∑n​i1​=Hn​

Proof via Rosenthal’s potential function

先证明：所有的玩家使用 1i\frac{1}{i}i1​ 一步到位的路径确实是纯纳什均衡的。

  • 当所有玩家使用上面那条路径时候，没有 player has incentive to deviate to 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ path since 1+ϵ>1i(∀i=1,⋯ )1+\epsilon\gt\frac{1}{i}(\forall i=1,\cdots)1+ϵ>i1​(∀i=1,⋯).

再证明：这个所有玩家使用一步到位的路径的纯纳什均衡是唯一的。只要有人选择 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ 的路径，那么就不是纳什均衡的。

  • S′S'S′: 假设有的人走 1i1\over ii1​ 一步到位的路径，有的人走 000，再走 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ 的路径。We will show that S′S'S′ is not Pure Nash Equilibrium for every ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0.

  • Consider there are lll players using 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ path. Among the players who use the direct edge to τ\tauτ let i∗i^*i∗ be the player of minimum index.

  • It must be that i∗≤l+1i^*\le l+1i∗≤l+1. If i∗≤li^*\le li∗≤l, cost is at least 1l1\over ll1​ By deviating the cost would be 1+ϵl+1<1l\frac{1+\epsilon}{l+1}\lt\frac{1}{l}l+11+ϵ​<l1​.

  • When i∗=l+1i^*=l+1i∗=l+1 i.e., 1,⋯ ,l1,\cdots,l1,⋯,l-th players using 1+ϵ1+\epsilon1+ϵ edge. The remaining players use direct edge.

    Player lll has cost 1+ϵl\frac{1+\epsilon}{l}l1+ϵ​. By deviating to the direct yields smaller cost 1l1\over ll1​.

    Therefore S∗S^*S∗ is not PNE.

SC(Seq)≤Hn×SC(S∗)⇒PoS=min⁡S∈PNESC(S)SC(S∗)≤SC(Seq)SC(S∗)≤HnSC(S_{eq})\le H_n\times SC(S^*)\\\Rarr PoS=\min_{S\in PNE}\frac{SC(S)}{SC(S^*)}\le\frac{SC(S_{eq})}{SC(S^*)}\le H_nSC(Seq​)≤Hn​×SC(S∗)⇒PoS=S∈PNEmin​SC(S∗)SC(S)​≤SC(S∗)SC(Seq​)​≤Hn​

Rosenthal’s potential is a potential function for network design game

Φ(S)=∑e∈E∑i=1fe(S)wei=∑e∈E;fe(S)>0weHfe(S)≤∑e∈E;fe(S)>0weHnSC(S)=∑e∈E;fe(S)>0we≤∑e∈E;fe(S)>0weHfe(S)=Φ(S)SC(Seq)≤Φ(Seq)≤Φ(S∗)≤HnSC(S∗)\Phi(S)=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{i=1}^{f_e(S)}\frac{w_e}{i}=\sum_{e\in E;f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}\le\sum_{e\in E;f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_n\\SC(S)=\sum_{e\in E;f_e(S)\gt0}w_e\le\sum_{e\in E;f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}=\Phi(S)\\SC(S_{eq})\le\Phi(S_{eq})\le\Phi(S^*)\le H_nSC(S^*)Φ(S)=e∈E∑​i=1∑fe​(S)​iwe​​=e∈E;fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​≤e∈E;fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hn​SC(S)=e∈E;fe​(S)>0∑​we​≤e∈E;fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​=Φ(S)SC(Seq​)≤Φ(Seq​)≤Φ(S∗)≤Hn​SC(S∗)

S,S′S,S'S,S′ states that differ in the strategy of player iii.

Strategy of player iii: S=(s−i,si),S′=(s−i,si′)S=(s_{-i},s_i),S'=(s_{-i},s_i')S=(s−i​,si​),S′=(s−i​,si′​)

Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=∑e∈E;fe(S)>0weHfe(S)−∑e∈E;fe(S′)>0weHfe(s′)(∗)\Phi(S)-\Phi(S')=\sum_{e\in E;f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}-\sum_{e\in E;f_e(S')\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(s')}(*)Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=e∈E;fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​−e∈E;fe​(S′)>0∑​we​Hfe​(s′)​(∗)

4 cases

  1. E1E_1E1​: edges used by iii in both SSS and S′S'S′
  2. E2E_2E2​: edges used by iii in SSS not in S′S'S′.
  3. E3E_3E3​: edges used by iii in S′S'S′ not in SSS.
  4. E4E_4E4​: edges neither used by iii in SSS nor S′S'S′

(∗)=∑e∈E1,fe(S)>0weHfe(S)+∑e∈E2,fe(S)>0weHfe(S)+∑e∈E3,fe(S)>0weHfe(S)+∑e∈E4,fe(S)>0weHfe(S)−∑e∈E1,fe(S′)>0weHfe(S′)−∑e∈E2,fe(S′)>0weHfe(S′)−∑e∈E3,fe(S′)>0weHfe(S′)−∑e∈E4,fe(S′)>0weHfe(S′)=∑e∈E1,fe(S)>0,fe(S′)>0we(Hfe(S)−Hfe(S′))+∑e∈E2,fe(S)>0we(Hfe(S)−Hfe(S′))+∑e∈E3,fe(S′)>0we(Hfe(S)−Hfe(S′))+∑e∈E4,fe(S)>0,fe(S′)>0we(Hfe(S)−Hfe(S′))=∑e∈E1,fe(S)>0,fe(S′)>0(wefe(S)−wefe(S′))+∑e∈E2,fe(S)>0wefe(S)−∑e∈E3,fe(S′)>0wefe(S′)−0=∑e∈siwefe(S)−∑e∈si′wefe(S′)=costi(S)−costi(S′)(*)=\sum_{e\in E_1,f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}+\sum_{e\in E_2,f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}+\sum_{e\in E_3,f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}+\sum_{e\in E_4,f_e(S)\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S)}\\-\sum_{e\in E_1,f_e(S')\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S')}-\sum_{e\in E_2,f_e(S')\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S')}-\sum_{e\in E_3,f_e(S')\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S')}-\sum_{e\in E_4,f_e(S')\gt0}w_eH_{f_e(S')}\\=\sum_{e\in E_1,f_e(S)\gt0,f_e(S')\gt0}w_e(H_{f_e(S)}-H_{f_e(S')})+\sum_{e\in E_2,f_e(S)\gt0}w_e(H_{f_e(S)}-H_{f_e(S')})\\+\sum_{e\in E_3,f_e(S')\gt0}w_e(H_{f_e(S)}-H_{f_e(S')})+\sum_{e\in E_4,f_e(S)\gt0,f_e(S')\gt0}w_e(H_{f_e(S)}-H_{f_e(S')})\\=\cancel{\sum_{e\in E_1,f_e(S)\gt0,f_e(S')\gt0}(\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}-\frac{w_e}{f_e(S')})}+\sum_{e\in E_2,f_e(S)\gt0}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}-\sum_{e\in E_3,f_e(S')\gt0}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S')}-\cancel0\\=\sum_{e\in s_i}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S)}-\sum_{e\in s_i'}\frac{w_e}{f_e(S')}=\text{cost}_i(S)-\text{cost}_i(S')(∗)=e∈E1​,fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​+e∈E2​,fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​+e∈E3​,fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​+e∈E4​,fe​(S)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S)​−e∈E1​,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S′)​−e∈E2​,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S′)​−e∈E3​,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S′)​−e∈E4​,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​Hfe​(S′)​=e∈E1​,fe​(S)>0,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​(Hfe​(S)​−Hfe​(S′)​)+e∈E2​,fe​(S)>0∑​we​(Hfe​(S)​−Hfe​(S′)​)+e∈E3​,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​(Hfe​(S)​−Hfe​(S′)​)+e∈E4​,fe​(S)>0,fe​(S′)>0∑​we​(Hfe​(S)​−Hfe​(S′)​)=e∈E1​,fe​(S)>0,fe​(S′)>0∑​(fe​(S)we​​−fe​(S′)we​​)​+e∈E2​,fe​(S)>0∑​fe​(S)we​​−e∈E3​,fe​(S′)>0∑​fe​(S′)we​​−0​=e∈si​∑​fe​(S)we​​−e∈si′​∑​fe​(S′)we​​=costi​(S)−costi​(S′)

entry.title: 计算机视觉 W48 Roundup - Uncovered Areas (新课完结)
entry.content:
Cross-entropy revisited

Binary cross-entropy loss

J(w)=−∑i=1n(y(i)log⁡(hw(x(i)))+(1−y(i))log⁡(1−hw(x(i))))=−∑i=1n∑k=011{y(i)=k}log⁡(Pr⁡(y(i)=k∣x(i)))J(w)=-\sum_{i=1}^n(y^{(i)}\log(h_w(x^{(i)}))+(1-y^{(i)})\log(1-h_w(x^{(i)})))\\=-\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{k=0}^1\mathbf 1\{y^{(i)}=k\}\log(\Pr(y^{(i)}=k|x^{(i)}))J(w)=−i=1∑n​(y(i)log(hw​(x(i)))+(1−y(i))log(1−hw​(x(i))))=−i=1∑n​k=0∑1​1{y(i)=k}log(Pr(y(i)=k∣x(i)))

categorical cross entropy loss is used for multi-class classification. similar

Where does loss function actually come from?

entropy, cross entropy and KL divergence

Entropy

information entropy is a measure of the uncertainty associated with a given probability distribution Pr⁡(xi)\Pr(x_i)Pr(xi​)

formally defined as the average amount of information you get from one random sample, drawn from a probability distribution ppp

the concept is due to Claude Shannon and was introduced in 1948

the goal is to reliably send a message from a sender to a recipient

messages are composed of bits, but not all bits are useful: some are redundant, some are error etc.

so when we send a message, we want as much useful information as possible to get through

In Shannon’s theory, sending one bit of information means to reduce the receiver’s uncertainty by a factor of two.

幻灯片有一个以天气预报为例解释信息熵的例子

the probability distribution is:

H(p)=−∑i=1npilog⁡2(pi)H(\mathbb p)=-\sum_{i=1}^np_i\log_2(p_i)H(p)=−i=1∑n​pi​log2​(pi​)

Cross-entropy

the cross entropy between two probability distributions ppp and qqq over the same underlying set of events measures the average number of bits needed to identify an event drawn from the set if a coding scheme used for the set is optimized for an estimated probability distribution qqq, rather than the true distribution ppp.

幻灯片有一个以天气预报为例解释交叉熵的例子

note that if the predicted probabilities equal the true probabilities, then the cross-entropy is just the entropy.

but if the two distribution differ, the cross-entropy will be larger than the entropy by some number of bits.

交叉熵实际上就是衡量两个我预测的概率分布和真实的概率分布差距的大小。

H(p,q)=−∑i=1npilog⁡2(qi)H(\mathbb p,\mathbb q)=-\sum_{i=1}^np_i\log_2(q_i)H(p,q)=−i=1∑n​pi​log2​(qi​)

pip_ipi​: true underlying distribution

qiq_iqi​: predicted distribution

Effect of KL loss term in VAEs

DKL(p∣∣q)=H(p,q)−H(p)D_{KL}(\mathbb p||\mathbb q)=H(\mathbb p,\mathbb q)-H(\mathbb p)DKL​(p∣∣q)=H(p,q)−H(p)

KL 散度就是交叉熵减去信息熵。

the amount by which the cross-entropy exceeds the entropy, is called the relative entropy, or Kullback-Leibler Divergence.

the KL loss term pushes the latent representation towards a standard normal distribution, i.e., the i-th element is Zi∼N(0,1)Z_i\sim N(0,1)Zi​∼N(0,1).

Application in softmax regression

we need a loss function that compares the predicted probabilities with the true probabilities.

use cross-entropy to compare them.

Wrap-up on GANs

generator network: try to fool the discriminator by generating real-looking images

discriminator network: try to distinguish between real and fake images.

DCGAN = GAN + Deep Convolution

Conditional GAN

  • the original GAN generates data from random noise but has no knowledge about class labels.
  • CGAN aims to solve this issue by telling the generator to generate images of only one particular class, like a cat or a dog.
  • specifically, CGAN concatenates a one-hot vector y\mathbb yy to the random noise vector z\mathbb zz to result in an architecture.

Pix2Pix

CycleGAN

ProGAN - aka progressive growing of GAN - purpose is to generate high resolution images

BigGAN

Common problems in training GANs

non-convergence

mode collapse

diminished gradient

unbalanced between G and D

highly sensitive to hyper-parameter selections.

Stabilizing GAN training

WGAN proposes a new loss function that has some nice properties that lead to a higher quality of the gradients to train the generator.

Diffusion Models

Motivation

GAN and VAE convert noise vector to image in a single forward pass.

fast but hard to learn a model

diffusion model generate image from noise by iterative denoising

slow but much easier to learn

Recall Denoising Autoencoder

train an autoencoder to undo the effect of a corruption process stochastically applied to the input

the underlying idea is very simple: add random noise to the input and teach the auto encoder to remove the noise.

Basic idea - 2 process

  1. pre-defined forward diffusion: gradually adds noise to the input

    一共 t 步，每一步都加一点高斯噪声。有专门的公式去控制。

    diffusion kernel q(Xt∣X0)=N(xt;αtx0,(1−αt)I)q(X_t|X_0)=\mathcal N(x_t;\sqrt{\alpha_t}x_0,(1-\alpha_t)I)q(Xt​∣X0​)=N(xt​;αt​​x0​,(1−αt​)I)

  2. reverse denoising: neural network is trained to gradually denoise the data, starting from pure noise.

    neural network: approximate these conditional probabilities in order to run the reverse diffusion process.

（此处省略了一些有关 diffusion model 的细节）

Conditional diffusion models

an additional input yyy (class label or a text sequence) is available and we try to model the conditional distribution p(x∣y)p(x|y)p(x∣y) instead.

in practice, the denoising model is also conditioned on yyy in addition to the image from the previous timestep xtx_txt​.

this allows us to generate data given the conditioning signal.

Classifier-guided diffusion model

main idea: train an extra classifier and mix its gradient with the diffusion model during sampling

CLIP-guided diffusion model

given an image xxx and prompt yyy, a CLIP model computes the alignment cosine similarity of x and y, which indicates how similar the image and the prompt are.

to use this signal for guidance, we assume that the CLIP similarity score is a good estimation of the function p(y∣x)p(y|x)p(y∣x).

the gradient of this score w.r.t. the noised image, xtx_txt​ at timestep ttt is used as the guidance gardient.

note that this requires the CLIP model to compute score for noised-images at intermediate timestep, hence a noised CLIP model is trained for guidance.

DALL-E and Stable Diffusion

encoding from CLIP as the target encoding

用类似于 inverting CNN 的东西，找到相似 latent feature 表达的图。

DALL-E 2: conditioning on CLIP-embeddings

  • helps capture multimodal representations
  • the bi-partite latent enables several text-controlled image manipulation tasks

Stable Diffusion

  • text embedding: describes the content in words
  • random noise: random initialization, unique generated image every time

Latent Diffusion Models

LDM applies the diffusion processes in the latent space instead of pixel space while incorporating semantic feed back from a transformer.

not only memory efficient, they also produce diverse, highly detailed images which preserve the semantic structure of the data.

Conditioned Latent Diffusion

the image generation task is conditioned on a prior

denoising U-Net autoencoder with cross-attention (Q, K, V)

Attention revisited

Self-attention in CNNs

Self-attention in GANs aka SAGAN

  • add the attention weights back onto input layer itself with a weight of gamma, a learnable parameter initializing at 0. It means that the self-attention module does not do anything initially.

attention U-Net

  • during unsampling in the decoder, spatial information recreated is imprecise. to counteract this problem, the U-Net uses skip-connections that utilize spatial information from the down-sampling in the encoder. Attention gates implemented at the skip connection will actively suppress activations in irrelevant regions, reducing the number of redundant features brought across.

CBAM aka convolutional block attention module

  • attention module for CNN
  • given an intermediate feature map, the module sequentially infers attention maps along two separate dimensions, channels and spatial, then the attention maps are multiplied to the input feature map for adaptive feature refinement.

Self-supervised learning

goal: learn from data without manual label annotation

self-supervised learning methods solve pretext tasks that produce good features for downstream tasks

learn with supervised learning objectives e.g. classification, regression

labels of these pretext tasks are generated automatically.

How to evaluate an SSL method?

we usually don’t care about the performance of the self-supervised learning task e.g., we don’t care if the model learns to predict image rotation perfectly.

evaluate the learned feature encoder on downstream target tasks.

pretext task: predict rotations

self-supervised learning by rotating the entire input image

the model learns to predict which rotation is applied

evaluation on semi-supervised learning

self-supervised learning on CIFAR10

freeze conv1 + conv2 learn conv3 + linear layers with subset of labeled CIFAR10 data.

other pretext tasks

  • solving jigsaw puzzles 拼图游戏
  • predict relative path locations
  • predict missing pixels
  • image coloring

Summary: pretext tasks from transformations

pretext tasks focus on visual common sense

the model are forced to learn good features about natural images e.g. semantic representation of an object category, in order to solve the pretext tasks

we don’t care about the performance of these pretext tasks, but rather how useful the learned features are for downstream tasks.

problems:

  • coming up with individual pretext tasks is tedious
  • the learned representations may not be general

A more general pretext task

contrastive representation learning

  • given a chosen score function, we aim to learn an encoder network fff that yields high score for positive pairs and low score for negative pairs

Masked Autoencoder

（当时在华为实习的时候我就搞的这玩意……）

CLIP

Siamese network

motivation

assume that we want to build a face recognition system for a small organization with only 10 employees

using a traditional classification approach, we might come up with a system like: 输入图片 - 分类器 - 输出是每个种类对应概率值。

problem

  1. to train such a system, we first require a lot of different images of each of the 10 person in the organization which might not be feasible.
  2. what if a new person joins or leaves the organization? you need to take the pain of collecting data again and re-train the entire model again.

Siamese network helps to solve both of above issues, instead of directly classifying an input image to one of the 10 people in the organization, this network instead takes an extra reference image of the person as input and produces a similarity score denoting the chances that the two input images belong to the same person.

notice that this network is not learning to classify an image directly to any of the output classes, rather, it is learning a similarity function, which takes two images as input and expresses how similar they are.

in practice:

  • to train this network, don’t require too many instances of a class and only few are enough to build a good model.
  • but the biggest advantage is that, let’s say in case of face recognition, we have a new employee who has joined the organization. new in order for the network to detect his/her face, we only require a single image of his/her face which will be stored in the database. using this as the reference image, the network will calculate the similarity for any new instance presented to it. Thus, we say that network predicts the score in one shot.

Architecture

将检测图和对比图输入同一个 ConvNet 中，分别得到两个图的 encoding，再将这两个 encoding 拿到判别其中，检查相似度，在经过 sigmoid 函数激活后得到相似度打分。
entry.summary:
Cross-entropy revisited

Binary cr

entry.title: 计算几何 W47 Voronoi Diagrams and 3D Convex Hull
entry.content:
Voronoi Diagrams

nnn points p1,⋯ ,pnp_1,\cdots,p_np1​,⋯,pn​.

Nearest neighbor problem

举一个具象化的例子：

nnn post offices

Find the closest post office

For which region, point pip_ipi​ is the closest point?

What is the region that pip_ipi​ servies?

（对于二维空间使用欧几里得距离定义的距离）两个最近点对连线线段的中垂线就是分界。

Definition of Voronoi Diagrams

A set PPP of nnn points p1,⋯ ,pnp_1,\cdots,p_np1​,⋯,pn​

decomposition of R2\mathbb R^2R2 into regions R1,⋯ ,RnR_1,\cdots,R_nR1​,⋯,Rn​.

for any q∈Riq\in R_iq∈Ri​, pip_ipi​ is the closest point

Theorems

Cells of the Voronoi diagram of PPP are convex.

Proof:

Consider pip_ipi​. Draw the bisector of pipj‾,j≠i\overline{p_ip_j},j\neq ipi​pj​​,j=i and let hjh_jhj​ be the half space the contains the side of the bisector that includes pip_ipi​. The cell of pip_ipi​ is the intersection of all hjh_jhj​’s.

If not all points of PPP lie on a line, the Voronoi diagram is made of straight line segments or rays and it is connected.

  • the cells are convex regions from the previous proof
  • the finite cells are polygons
  • if there is a full line lll, then it implies that no bisector intersects lll, which means all points lie on a line.

The size of a planar Voronoi diagram is linear.

Proof:

mmm: number of edges in Voronoi graph, III: number of vertices in Voronoi graph, HHH: size infinite cell

Euler’s Formula: V−E+R=2V-E+R=2V−E+R=2

For infinite edges:

  • put a bounding box，加入边界盒后的点数为 VVV，边数为 EEE，面数为 RRR.
  • R=n+1R=n+1R=n+1 one for each input point + outside
  • all vertices have degree three, except four special corner vertices
  • 2E=3(V−4)+4×22E=3(V-4)+4\times 22E=3(V−4)+4×2
  • E=4+H+m,V=4+H+IE=4+H+m,V=4+H+IE=4+H+m,V=4+H+I

一顿推导，得出：

I=2n−2−H≤2n−5I=2n-2-H\le2n-5I=2n−2−H≤2n−5

m=3n−H−3≤3n−6m=3n-H-3\le3n-6m=3n−H−3≤3n−6

Computing 2D Voronoi Diagrams

idea: sweep line

problem: the next point, can totally change everything above the sweep line.

we cannot assume we have compute the diagram above the sweep line correctly.

idea: define a region above the sweep line that we know is stable. Anything in this region is closer to ppp than any point below the line i.e. cell of ccc above the curve is stable.

sweep line: Y=lY=lY=l

curve: Pi(l)=(X−ai)2+(Y−bi)2=(Y−l)2P_i(l)=(X-a_i)^2+(Y-b_i)^2=(Y-l)^2Pi​(l)=(X−ai​)2+(Y−bi​)2=(Y−l)2

Initially, all the Y-coordinates are the event points.

挨着向下扫描，在扫描线上方的点，两两之间用中垂线 bisector 分隔开，扫描线上方的点和扫描线用抛物线分隔开。这样得到的区域就是稳定的。

Other event points are when parabola segment disappear.

Can be found by checking three adjacent parabola segments.

We need a data structure for inserting and deleting parabola segments i.e., a balanced BST.

O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn) running time:

log⁡n\log nlogn pere event points

O(n)O(n)O(n) events points (since size of the diagram is linear)

Generalization of Voronoi Diagrams

farthest point Voronoi diagram

higher order nearest neighbor

kkk-order: same set of kkk nearest neighbors

different distance measure L∞,L1⋯L_\infty,L_1\cdotsL∞​,L1​⋯

segments, curves etc.

distance based on shape enlarging

Triangulations

Let PPP be set of nnn points in R2\mathbb R^2R2

Theorem: Any trangulation of PPP has 2n−2−k2n-2-k2n−2−k triangles and 3n−3−k3n-3-k3n−3−k edges.

kkk is number of edges on Convex Hull of PPP.

edge e=pq‾e=\overline{pq}e=pq​ is illegal if min⁡α<min⁡β\min\alpha\lt\min\betaminα<minβ.

Observation: Let eee be an illegaal edge of T\mathcal TT, let T′\mathcal T'T′ be triangulation obtained from T\mathcal TT by flipping eee, then A(T′)>A(T)A(\mathcal T')\gt A(\mathcal T)A(T′)>A(T)

Pseudo code for legal triangulation:

  1. while T\mathcal TT contains illegal edge e=pq‾e=\overline{pq}e=pq​

    let rrr and sss be the other points in the triangles incident to eee

    remove eee and add st‾\overline{st}st

  2. return T\mathcal TT

The Delaunay Triangulation

Let PPP be set of nnn points in R2\mathbb R^2R2, let V(P)\mathcal V(P)V(P) be the Voronoi diagram of PPP.

Let D(P)\mathcal D(P)D(P) be the dual graph of V(P)\mathcal V(P)V(P), D(P)\mathcal D(P)D(P) is the Delaunay graph of PPP. 沃诺依图的对偶图是德劳内三角剖分

Theorem: D(P)\mathcal D(P)D(P) is a plane graph

Assume that PPP is in geneal position: no four points cocircular, not three points colinear.

Theorem:

  1. p,q,r∈Pp,q,r\in Pp,q,r∈P are vertices of the same face of D(P)⇔\mathcal D(P)\LrarrD(P)⇔ circle through p,q,rp,q,rp,q,r contains no other point of PPP in its interior.
  2. p,q∈Pp,q\in Pp,q∈P from an edge of D(P)⇔\mathcal D(P)\LrarrD(P)⇔ there is a closed disk CCC that contains ppp and qqq on its boundary and doesn’t contain any other point of PPP

Computing Delaunay Triangulation

using randomized incremental construction

as with point location, we maintain T\mathcal TT and a point location data structure D\mathcal DD.

3D Convex Hull

convex hull ofo nnn points in 3D3D3D

composed of

  • vertices
  • edges
  • faces

Complexity of a 3D CH is linear

  1. 假设边是“线”： 在计算几何的上下文中，这里的“线”指的是 3D 凸包的边。 这些边形成凸包的边界。
  2. 从放置在凸包顶点顶部的光源投射边缘的阴影： 想象一下，您有一个光源直接位于凸包最高点（顶点）上方。 现在，将每条边的阴影投影到凸包下方的平坦表面上。 这类似于物体在光照射下投射的阴影。
  3. 由于凸性，边缘的阴影不会交叉： 因为根据定义，凸包是凸形状，因此当投影到平面上时，其边缘的阴影不会相交或相互交叉。 该特性是船体凸度的直接结果。
  4. 由于我们是从不在凸包外部的点进行投影： 投影是从凸包内部的点（具体来说，在最高顶点的顶部）完成的。 这确保了阴影投射在凸包内而不是外部。

Gift Wrapping for 3DCH

wrap a plane around the convex hull

  1. project the points to 2D, find the 2D CH
  2. an edge of 2D CH is a starting point
  3. perform a DFS on the faces. (the face is marked so we don’t visit it again)

O(nh)O(nh)O(nh) time, nnn is number of points, hhh is output size.

Randomized Incremental Algorithm for 3DCH

  1. randomly shuffle the points
  2. create the convex hull of the first four points
  3. for i=1,⋯ ,ni=1,\cdots,ni=1,⋯,n insert pip_ipi​

adding pip_ipi​:

  1. faces visible from pip_ipi​ should be removed
  2. new faces should be added, touching the boundary of the formerly visible faces

an edges is a boundary edge if out of two faces next to it one is visible but the other is not.

to find the visible faces

  • for every point ppp maintain a list of faces l(p)l(p)l(p) visible from ppp
  • for every face fff maintain a list of points l(f)l(f)l(f) visible from fff
  • for every face f∈l(p)f\in l(p)f∈l(p) place a point and back to the pointer p∈l(f)p\in l(f)p∈l(f).

the points that can see fff, l(f)l(f)l(f) is a subset of points that can see f1f_1f1​ and f2f_2f2​, l(f)⊂l(f1)∪l(f2)l(f)\sub l(f_1)\cup l(f_2)l(f)⊂l(f1​)∪l(f2​)

如果一个点能同时看到两个相邻的面，那么这个点一定在这两个面延长面共同的上方。

if FiF_iFi​ is the list of faces visible from pip_ipi​ then adding pip_ipi​ takes ∑f∈Fi∣l(f)∣\sum_{f\in F_i}|l(f)|∑f∈Fi​​∣l(f)∣ time asymptotically

i.e. O(ni)O(\frac{n}{i})O(in​) on average.

O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn) expected running time
entry.summary: Voronoi Diagrams

entry.title: 算法博弈论 W47 Congestion games, potential functions
entry.content:
Atomic selfish routing

3 players: strategies: connect source sis_isi​ with destination tit_iti​.

Assuming that all edges have latency functions ce(x)=xc_e(x)=xce​(x)=x how do the players act?

肯定尽量选不挤的路径。

Load balancing games

Every player has a job and wants to assign it to some machine so that its completion time is minimized

mmm parallel machines

  • Machine jjj has speed σj\sigma_jσj​
  • If machine jjj gets xxx jobs, the latency/cost experienced by each of the players/owners of these jobs is xσj\frac{x}{\sigma_j}σj​x​.

Similar to atomic selfish routing with among nnn players who want to route from a common source sss to a common destination ttt through mmm parallel edges of latency function cj(x)=xσjc_j(x)=\frac{x}{\sigma_j}cj​(x)=σj​x​.

Congestion games

Set NNN of nnn players, set EEE with mmm resources

Resource eee has latency function ce:N→R≥0c_e:N\rightarrow\mathbb R_{\ge0}ce​:N→R≥0​

  • Non-decreasing, denotes the latency caused by the resources to the players who use it.

Player iii has a set of strategies Σi\Sigma_iΣi​.

  • Every strategy is a set of resources (denotes the resources used by the player)

State S=(s1,⋯ ,sn)S=(s_1,\cdots,s_n)S=(s1​,⋯,sn​), where player iii selects strategy si∈Σis_i\in\Sigma_isi​∈Σi​,

Load fe(S)f_e(S)fe​(S) of resource eee at state S=S=S= number of players who use resource eee at state SSS.

Hence, the quantity ce(fe(S))c_e(f_e(S))ce​(fe​(S)) denotes the latency incurred by resource eee to the players who use it.

Cost/latency of player iii at state SSS:

costi(S)=∑e∈sice(fe(S))\text{cost}_i(S)=\sum_{e\in s_i}c_e(f_e(S))costi​(S)=e∈si​∑​ce​(fe​(S))

Every player aims at minimizing own cost

Pure Nash equilibrium: costi≤costi(S−i,s)\text{cost}_i\le\text{cost}_i(S_{-i},s)costi​≤costi​(S−i​,s) for every strategy s∈Σis\in\Sigma_is∈Σi​ of player iii

Potential functions

Definition: Function Φ:S→R\Phi:\mathbf S\rightarrow\mathbb RΦ:S→R is a potential function if for every two states S1S_1S1​ and S2S_2S2​ that differ in the strategy of a single player iii, the differences Φ(S1)−Φ(S2)\Phi(S_1)-\Phi(S_2)Φ(S1​)−Φ(S2​) and costi(S1)−costi(S2)\text{cost}_i(S_1)-\text{cost}_i(S_2)costi​(S1​)−costi​(S2​) have the same sign.

Potential games: those admitting a potential function

Theorem: Every potential game have at least one pure Nash equilibrium

Proof

Consider the Nash dynamics graph which has a node for each state of the game and a directed edge from state SSS to state S′S'S′ if they differ in the strategy of a single player iii, who improves cost when deviating from the strategy she uses in state SSS to the strategy she uses in state S′S'S′.

By definition of the potential function Φ\PhiΦ, the potential value Φ(S)\Phi(S)Φ(S) is strictly higher than Φ(S′)\Phi(S')Φ(S′). Then, the Nash dynamics graph can not have directed cycles. This implies that there will be a node which is a sink i.e., it has only incoming edges. Let SSS be such the state corresponding to this node. Then, no player has an incentive to deviate from SSS. Thus, SSS is a pure Nash equilibrium.

Rosenthal’s potential function

Theorem: for every congestion games, the function

Φ(S)=∑e∈E∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)\Phi(S)=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)Φ(S)=e∈E∑​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)

is a potential function.

Proof

We will show that for two states S1,S2S_1,S_2S1​,S2​ that different in the strategy of player iii, it holds Φ(S1)−Φ(S2)=costi(S1)−costi(S2)\Phi(S_1)-\Phi(S_2)=\text{cost}_i(S_1)-\text{cost}_i(S_2)Φ(S1​)−Φ(S2​)=costi​(S1​)−costi​(S2​).

By the definition of Rosenthal’s potential function, we have

Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=∑e∈E∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑e∈E∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j)=∑e∈E(∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j))=∑e∉si∪si′(∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j))+∑e∈si∩si′(∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j))+∑e∈si╲si′(∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j))+∑e∈si′╲si(∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j))\Phi(S)-\Phi(S')=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)\\=\sum_{e\in E}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)\right)\\=\sum_{e\notin s_i\cup s_i'}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)\right)+\sum_{e\in s_i\cap s_i'}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)\right)\\+\sum_{e\in s_i\diagdown s_i'}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)\right)+\sum_{e\in s_i'\diagdown s_i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)\right)Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=e∈E∑​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)−e∈E∑​j=1∑fe​(S′)​ce​(j)=e∈E∑​⎝⎛​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)−j=1∑fe​(S′)​ce​(j)⎠⎞​=e∈/si​∪si′​∑​⎝⎛​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)−j=1∑fe​(S′)​ce​(j)⎠⎞​+e∈si​∩si′​∑​⎝⎛​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)−j=1∑fe​(S′)​ce​(j)⎠⎞​+e∈si​╲si′​∑​⎝⎛​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)−j=1∑fe​(S′)​ce​(j)⎠⎞​+e∈si′​╲si​∑​⎝⎛​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)−j=1∑fe​(S′)​ce​(j)⎠⎞​

Now, we can observe the following

  1. if e∉si∪si′e\notin s_i\cup s_i'e∈/si​∪si′​, then fe(S)=fe(S′)f_e(S)=f_e(S')fe​(S)=fe​(S′) and hence, ∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j)=0\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)=0∑j=1fe​(S)​ce​(j)−∑j=1fe​(S′)​ce​(j)=0
  2. if e∈si∩si′e\in s_i\cap s_i'e∈si​∩si′​, then fe(S)=fe(S′)f_e(S)=f_e(S')fe​(S)=fe​(S′) and hence, ∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j)=ce(fe(S))−ce(fe(S′))\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)=c_e(f_e(S))-c_e(f_e(S'))∑j=1fe​(S)​ce​(j)−∑j=1fe​(S′)​ce​(j)=ce​(fe​(S))−ce​(fe​(S′))
  3. if e∈si╲si′e\in s_i\diagdown s_i'e∈si​╲si′​, then fe(S)=fe(S′)+1f_e(S)=f_e(S')+1fe​(S)=fe​(S′)+1 and hence, ∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j)=ce(fe(S))\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)=c_e(f_e(S))∑j=1fe​(S)​ce​(j)−∑j=1fe​(S′)​ce​(j)=ce​(fe​(S))
  4. if e∈si′╲sie\in s_i'\diagdown s_ie∈si′​╲si​, then fe(S)=fe(S′)−1f_e(S)=f_e(S')-1fe​(S)=fe​(S′)−1 and hence, ∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)−∑j=1fe(S′)ce(j)=−ce(fe(S′))\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)-\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S')}c_e(j)=-c_e(f_e(S'))∑j=1fe​(S)​ce​(j)−∑j=1fe​(S′)​ce​(j)=−ce​(fe​(S′))

Thus, we have

Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=∑e∈si∩si′(ce(fe(S))−ce(fe(S′)))+∑e∈si╲si′ce(fe(S))−∑e∈si′╲sice(fe(S′))=∑e∈sice(fe(S))−∑e∈si′ce(fe(S′))=costi(S)−costi(S′)\Phi(S)-\Phi(S')=\sum_{e\in s_i\cap s_i'}(c_e(f_e(S))-c_e(f_e(S')))+\sum_{e\in s_i\diagdown s_i'}c_e(f_e(S))-\sum_{e\in s_i'\diagdown s_i}c_e(f_e(S'))\\=\sum_{e\in s_i}c_e(f_e(S))-\sum_{e\in s_i'}c_e(f_e(S'))\\=\text{cost}_i(S)-\text{cost}_i(S')Φ(S)−Φ(S′)=e∈si​∩si′​∑​(ce​(fe​(S))−ce​(fe​(S′)))+e∈si​╲si′​∑​ce​(fe​(S))−e∈si′​╲si​∑​ce​(fe​(S′))=e∈si​∑​ce​(fe​(S))−e∈si′​∑​ce​(fe​(S′))=costi​(S)−costi​(S′)

The social cost

Quantification of the performance of a system that is modeled by a strategic game

Typically SC(S)=∑i∈Ncosti(S)SC(S)=\sum_{i\in N}\text{cost}_i(S)SC(S)=∑i∈N​costi​(S)

The state that minimizes the social cost is not necessarily a pure Nash equilibrium.

So equilibrium are suboptimal

How is this sub-optimality quantified? Price of anarchy/Price of stability.

Price of stability/anarchy

PoS=min⁡s∈EQSC(s)SC(s∗)PoA=max⁡s∈EQSC(s)SC(s∗)PoS=\min_{s\in EQ}\frac{SC(s)}{SC(s^*)}\\PoA=\max_{s\in EQ}\frac{SC(s)}{SC(s^*)}PoS=s∈EQmin​SC(s∗)SC(s)​PoA=s∈EQmax​SC(s∗)SC(s)​

where s∗s^*s∗ denotes the optimal state i.e., one of minimum social cost.

PoS/PoA is an optimistic/pessimistic measure:

  • How close to/far from the optimal social cost can a system/game be due to strategic behavior

Linear Congestion games

Price of stability

Linear congestion games: resources eee has latency function

ce(x)=aex+bec_e(x)=a_ex+b_ece​(x)=ae​x+be​

Lemma: The social cost of a linear congestion game and Rosenthal’s potential function value at state SSS are connected with the inequalities

SC(S)2≤Φ(S)≤SC(S)\frac{SC(S)}{2}\le\Phi(S)\le SC(S)2SC(S)​≤Φ(S)≤SC(S)

Proof

By definition of latency functions in linear congestion games and the definition of the social cost, we have:

SC(S)=∑i∈Ncosti(S)=∑i∈N∑e∈sice(fe(S))=∑e∈Ece(fe(S))×∑i∈N:e∈si1=∑e∈Efe(S)(aefe(S)+be)=∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)be)SC(S)=\sum_{i\in N}\text{cost}_i(S)\\=\sum_{i\in N}\sum_{e\in s_i}c_e(f_e(S))\\=\sum_{e\in E}c_e(f_e(S))\times\sum_{i\in N:e\in s_i}1\\=\sum_{e\in E}f_e(S)(a_ef_e(S)+b_e)\\=\sum_{e\in E}(a_ef_e(S)^2+f_e(S)b_e)SC(S)=i∈N∑​costi​(S)=i∈N∑​e∈si​∑​ce​(fe​(S))=e∈E∑​ce​(fe​(S))×i∈N:e∈si​∑​1=e∈E∑​fe​(S)(ae​fe​(S)+be​)=e∈E∑​(ae​fe​(S)2+fe​(S)be​)

Also, by definition of Rosenthal’s potential function, we have:

Φ(S)=∑e∈E∑j=1fe(S)ce(j)=∑e∈E∑j=1fe(S)(aej+be)=∑e∈E(ae∑j=1fe(S)j+fe(S)be)=∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)2+fe(S)be)\Phi(S)=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}c_e(j)\\=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}(a_ej+b_e)\\=\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\sum_{j=1}^{f_e(S)}j+f_e(S)b_e\right)\\=\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\frac{f_e(S)^2+f_e(S)}{2}+f_e(S)b_e\right)Φ(S)=e∈E∑​j=1∑fe​(S)​ce​(j)=e∈E∑​j=1∑fe​(S)​(ae​j+be​)=e∈E∑​⎝⎛​ae​j=1∑fe​(S)​j+fe​(S)be​⎠⎞​=e∈E∑​(ae​2fe​(S)2+fe​(S)​+fe​(S)be​)

To prove the leftmost inequality in the statement of the lemma, it suffice to bound the potential function from below. Working with the equivalent expression for Φ(S)\Phi(S)Φ(S), we have:

Φ(S)=∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)2+fe(S)be)≥∑e∈E(aefe(S)22+befe(S))≥∑e∈E(aefe(S)22+befe(S)2)=12∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)be)=12SC(S)\Phi(S)=\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\frac{f_e(S)^2+f_e(S)}{2}+f_e(S)b_e\right)\\\ge\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\frac{f_e(S)^2}{2}+b_ef_e(S)\right)\\\ge\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\frac{f_e(S)^2}{2}+b_e\frac{f_e(S)}{2}\right)\\=\frac{1}{2}\sum_{e\in E}(a_ef_e(S)^2+f_e(S)b_e)\\=\frac{1}{2}SC(S)Φ(S)=e∈E∑​(ae​2fe​(S)2+fe​(S)​+fe​(S)be​)≥e∈E∑​(ae​2fe​(S)2​+be​fe​(S))≥e∈E∑​(ae​2fe​(S)2​+be​2fe​(S)​)=21​e∈E∑​(ae​fe​(S)2+fe​(S)be​)=21​SC(S)

For the rightmost inequality, we bound the potential function from above as follows:

Φ(S)=∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)2+fe(S)be)≤∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)22+fe(S)be)=∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+fe(S)be)=SC(S)\Phi(S)=\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\frac{f_e(S)^2+f_e(S)}{2}+f_e(S)b_e\right)\\\le\sum_{e\in E}\left(a_e\frac{f_e(S)^2+f_e(S)^2}{2}+f_e(S)b_e\right)\\=\sum_{e\in E}(a_ef_e(S)^2+f_e(S)b_e)\\=SC(S)Φ(S)=e∈E∑​(ae​2fe​(S)2+fe​(S)​+fe​(S)be​)≤e∈E∑​(ae​2fe​(S)2+fe​(S)2​+fe​(S)be​)=e∈E∑​(ae​fe​(S)2+fe​(S)be​)=SC(S)

Q. E. D.

Theorem: The PoS of linear congestion games is at most 2.

Proof

We use potential function method, We start from the state S∗S^*S∗ of minimum social cost. If it is a pure Nash equilibrium, then the price of stability is 111. Otherwise, we let the players change their strategies and improve their cost until we reach an equilibrium SSS. By Lemma above, we have SC(S)≤2Φ(S)SC(S)\le2\Phi(S)SC(S)≤2Φ(S), By the main property of the potential function, we have that Φ(S)≤Φ(S∗)\Phi(S)\le\Phi(S^*)Φ(S)≤Φ(S∗). Finally, again by Lemma above, we have that Φ(S∗)≤SC(S∗)\Phi(S^*)\le SC(S^*)Φ(S∗)≤SC(S∗). Thus,

SC(S)≤2Φ(S)≤2Φ(S∗)≤2SC(S∗)SC(S)\le2\Phi(S)\le2\Phi(S^*)\le2SC(S^*)SC(S)≤2Φ(S)≤2Φ(S∗)≤2SC(S∗)

The above bound is not best possible, An upper bound of 1+13≈1.5781+\frac{1}{\sqrt3}\approx 1.5781+3​1​≈1.578 has been proved.

A lower bound on the price of anarchy

4 player

graph LR1((σ1σ2))2((σ4τ2τ3))3((σ3τ1τ4))1-->|x|22-->|0|11-->|x|33-->|0|12-->|x|33-->|x|2

pure Nash equilibrium

  • Each player uses two edges
  • social cost = 10

optimal state:

  • every player uses her direct edge
  • social cost = 4
  • PoS=52PoS=\frac{5}{2}PoS=25​

A matching upper bound

Theorem: The price of anarchy of linear congestion game is at most 52\frac{5}{2}25​.

Proof（⚠️难度贼高的证明）

Lemma first

先证明引理 ∀x,y∈N,xy+y≤x23+5y23\forall x,y\in \mathbb N,xy+y\le\frac{x^2}{3}+\frac{5y^2}{3}∀x,y∈N,xy+y≤3x2​+35y2​.

⇔x2+5y2−3xy−3y≥0\Lrarr x^2+5y^2-3xy-3y\ge0⇔x2+5y2−3xy−3y≥0

Obviously true if y=0y=0y=0.

If y=1y=1y=1, we need to show that x2−3x+2≥0⇔(x−1)(x−2)≥0x^2-3x+2\ge0\Lrarr(x-1)(x-2)\ge0x2−3x+2≥0⇔(x−1)(x−2)≥0

显然成立，对于 x=1,2x=1,2x=1,2，二次函数=0，对于大于 3，小于 0，两项同号。

If y≥2y\ge2y≥2, 5y2−3y≥94y25y^2-3y\ge\frac{9}{4}y^25y2−3y≥49​y2, hence x2+5y2−3xy−3y>x2−3xy+94y2=(x−32y)2≥0x^2+5y^2-3xy-3y\gt x^2-3xy+\frac{9}{4}y^2=(x-\frac{3}{2}y)^2\ge0x2+5y2−3xy−3y>x2−3xy+49​y2=(x−23​y)2≥0.

引理证明完毕。（难点一：想出引理并证明）

Now consider a linear congestion game and let S∗=(s1∗,⋯ ,sn∗)S^*=(s_1^*,\cdots,s_n^*)S∗=(s1∗​,⋯,sn∗​) be the state of minimum social cost and S=(s1,⋯ ,sn)S=(s_1,\cdots,s_n)S=(s1​,⋯,sn​) a pure Nash equilibrium. Thus, at state SSS, no player iii has an incentive to change her strategy sis_isi​ to si∗s_i^*si∗​, i.e., for every player iii, it holds costi(S)≤costi(S−i,si∗)\text{cost}_i(S)\le\text{cost}_i(S_{-i},s_i^*)costi​(S)≤costi​(S−i​,si∗​)（这个放缩指的意思是，在一个纳什均衡状态下，某一个智能体单方面改变其策略只能是 social cost 增大）.

Summing over all players, we get

SC(S)=∑i∈Ncosti(S)≤∑i∈Ncosti(S−i,si∗)=∑i∈N∑e∈si∗ce(fe(S−i,si∗))=∑i∈N∑e∈si∗(aefe(S−i,si∗)+be)SC(S)=\sum_{i\in N}\text{cost}_i(S)\\\le\sum_{i\in N}\text{cost}_i(S_{-i},s_i^*)\\=\sum_{i\in N}\sum_{e\in s_i^*}c_e(f_e(S_{-i},s_i^*))\\=\sum_{i\in N}\sum_{e\in s_i^*}(a_ef_e(S_{-i},s_i^*)+b_e)SC(S)=i∈N∑​costi​(S)≤i∈N∑​costi​(S−i​,si∗​)=i∈N∑​e∈si∗​∑​ce​(fe​(S−i​,si∗​))=i∈N∑​e∈si∗​∑​(ae​fe​(S−i​,si∗​)+be​)

Notice that for every resource e∈Ee\in Ee∈E, it holds that fe(S−i,si∗)≤fe(S)+1f_e(S_{-i},s_i^*)\le f_e(S)+1fe​(S−i​,si∗​)≤fe​(S)+1（难点二（放缩）：对于任何一种资源，当一个智能体的策略改变时，该资源的负载最多是之前状态下的负载加 1，取等的条件是：智能体 iii 在策略 sis_isi​ 下没有使用资源 eee, 而在 si′s_i'si′​ 策略下使用了资源 eee） since only one player changes her strategy at state (S−i,si∗)(S_{-i},s_i^*)(S−i​,si∗​) compared to state SSS. Thus, we have:

SC(S)≤∑i∈N∑e∈si∗(ae(fe(S)+1)+be)=∑e∈E∑i∈N:e∈si∗(ae(fe(S)+1)+be)=∑e∈Efe(S∗)(ae(fe(S)+1)+be)=∑e∈E(aefe(S∗)fe(S)+aefe(S∗)+befe(S∗))SC(S)\le\sum_{i\in N}\sum_{e\in s_i^*}(a_e(f_e(S)+1)+b_e)\\=\sum_{e\in E}\sum_{i\in N:e\in s_i^*}(a_e(f_e(S)+1)+b_e)\\=\sum_{e\in E}f_e(S^*)(a_e(f_e(S)+1)+b_e)\\=\sum_{e\in E}(a_ef_e(S^*)f_e(S)+a_ef_e(S^*)+b_ef_e(S^*))SC(S)≤i∈N∑​e∈si∗​∑​(ae​(fe​(S)+1)+be​)=e∈E∑​i∈N:e∈si∗​∑​(ae​(fe​(S)+1)+be​)=e∈E∑​fe​(S∗)(ae​(fe​(S)+1)+be​)=e∈E∑​(ae​fe​(S∗)fe​(S)+ae​fe​(S∗)+be​fe​(S∗))

By applying Lemma above for x=fe(S),y=fe(S∗)x=f_e(S),y=f_e(S^*)x=fe​(S),y=fe​(S∗), we have:

SC(S)≤∑e∈E(13aefe(S)2+53aefe(S∗)2+befe(S∗))≤13∑e∈E(aefe(S)2+befe(S))+53∑e∈E(aefe(S∗)2+befe(S∗))=13SC(S)+53SC(S∗)SC(S)\le\sum_{e\in E}\left(\frac{1}{3}a_ef_e(S)^2+\frac{5}{3}a_ef_e(S^*)^2+b_ef_e(S^*)\right)\\\le\frac{1}{3}\sum_{e\in E}(a_ef_e(S)^2+b_ef_e(S))+\frac{5}{3}\sum_{e\in E}(a_ef_e(S^*)^2+b_ef_e(S^*))\\=\frac{1}{3}SC(S)+\frac{5}{3}SC(S^*)SC(S)≤e∈E∑​(31​ae​fe​(S)2+35​ae​fe​(S∗)2+be​fe​(S∗))≤31​e∈E∑​(ae​fe​(S)2+be​fe​(S))+35​e∈E∑​(ae​fe​(S∗)2+be​fe​(S∗))=31​SC(S)+35​SC(S∗)

Thus we conclude that SC(S)≤52SC(S∗)SC(S)\le\frac{5}{2}SC(S^*)SC(S)≤25​SC(S∗)

Q. E. D.
